title: Rutte favourite to be next NATO boss despite Dutch vote shock

content.background: Outgoing Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte is the clear front-runner to become NATO's next chief, even though a shock far-right win at elections in his homeland risks tarnishing his legacy.
content.summary: Outgoing Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte is the top candidate to become the next NATO Secretary General, with broad-based support from NATO heavyweights. Despite concerns over a far-right win in Dutch elections, diplomats believe Rutte's experience and commitment to defense investment make him a strong contender. Key factors influencing the selection process include the desire for a leader from a country meeting NATO's goal of spending 2% of GDP on defense and considerations regarding relations with the United States, particularly in light of a possible return of Donald Trump to the presidency. While some potential opposition exists, Rutte's candidacy is widely supported.

title: US stock market: Wall St ends lower amid Cyber Monday madness

content.background: This article discusses how the US stock market ended lower as investors paused after Thanksgiving and focused on the holiday shopping season, particularly Cyber Monday deals. It highlights the expected record spending by consumers during Cyber Monday and the impact of consumer spending on the US GDP. The article also mentions market concerns about the possibility of the Federal Reserve maintaining restrictive policy rates for longer than expected. It provides information on the performance of major stock indexes and sectors, as well as notable movements in specific stocks.
content.summary: US stocks edged lower as investors took a break after Thanksgiving to observe the holiday shopping season, particularly Cyber Monday deals. Retailers expected a record spending of $12 billion during Cyber Monday, indicating positive consumer health impacting the US GDP. Concerns arose over the Federal Reserve potentially keeping restrictive policies longer than anticipated. The article includes information on stock index performance, key sectors, and notable stock movements.

title: Gold climbs higher on dollar dip, Fed pause bets

content.background: Gold hit a six-month high on Monday as a softer dollar and expectations of a pause in the Federal Reserve's monetary tightening helped bullion consolidate above the key $2,000 an ounce level.
content.summary: Gold reached a six-month high due to a weaker dollar and speculation of a pause in the Federal Reserve's monetary tightening. The dollar's decline made gold more affordable for holders of other currencies. Traders anticipate the US central bank to maintain rates in December with a 50-50 chance of easing in May next year. Lower interest rates reduce the opportunity cost of holding non-interest-bearing assets, boosting gold prices. U.S. third-quarter GDP figures and the personal consumption expenditures price index will impact gold's future. China's net gold imports via Hong Kong declined for a second consecutive month. Silver, platinum, and palladium prices fluctuated.

title: RBI in CBDC talks with US & Hong Kong, Swift

content.background: India's banking regulator is exploring the feasibility of quick and inexpensive digital cross-border settlements using central bank digital currencies (CBDC). This could revolutionize cross-border payments and eliminate the need for traditional banking channels.
content.summary: India's Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is in discussions with counterparts in the US and Hong Kong, as well as Swift, to assess the potential for direct cross-border settlements using CBDC. The advantages of CBDC include quicker and cheaper transactions, but challenges and risks must be addressed. The RBI has previously emphasized the key role CBDCs can play in cross-border payments. Other countries, such as China and the US, are also piloting CBDCs. A recent report revealed that two-thirds of central banks globally, representing 98% of global GDP, are experimenting with CBDCs.
